cards.back:
Operational Amplifier

Named because it can perform mathematical operations (addition, subtraction, integration, differentiation) on signals.

cards.front: 741 Op-Amp: Which pin is the output?
cards.back:
Pin 6

Pin 2: Inverting input (-)
Pin 3: Non-inverting input (+)
Pin 4: V- (-15V)
Pin 7: V+ (+15V)

cards.front: What are the two golden rules for ideal op-amp analysis?
cards.back:
1. No current into inputs: I+ = I- = 0
2. Virtual short: V+ = V- (with negative feedback)

With negative feedback, V+ = V-

The inputs are at the same voltage but NOT physically connected. The op-amp adjusts its output to make this happen.

cards.front: Why is there no current into op-amp inputs?
cards.back:
Very high input impedance (megaohms)

By Ohm's law: I = V/R, high R means very small I.
We approximate this as zero for analysis.

When output reaches supply voltage limits and can't go higher.

For ±15V supply, output saturates at approximately ±14V.
Causes clipping/distortion of waveforms.

cards.front: What is open-loop gain of a 741 op-amp?
cards.back:
Approximately 200,000 (100 dB)

This enormous gain is why the virtual short approximation works.

cards.front: Why do op-amp circuits use negative feedback?
cards.back:
To control the gain!

Open-loop: Gain = 200,000 (saturates immediately)
Closed-loop: Gain is controlled by external resistors (e.g., 10, 100).

Gain × Bandwidth = GBP (constant)

741 has GBP = 1MHz
If Gain = 100, Bandwidth = 10kHz
If Gain = 10, Bandwidth = 100kHz

1. Write KCL at inverting node
2. Write KCL at non-inverting node
3. Set V+ = V- (virtual short)
4. Solve for gain (Vo/Vi)
